title: United States Custom House, Court House, and Post Office (Chicago, Illinois, 1880)
text:
The United States Custom House, Court House, and Post Office was a federal government building from the 1870s to 1896 in the block bounded by Adams Street, Jackson Boulevard, Dearborn Street, and <a href="Clark%20Street%20%28Chicago%29">Clark Street</a> in the <a href="Chicago%20Loop">Chicago Loop</a>
History.
The supervising architect was James G. Gill. It was completed in 1880, but already occupied by 1879.
Federal courts meeting in this building were the <a href="United%20States%20District%20Court%20for%20the%20Northern%20District%20of%20Illinois">United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois</a> (1879 to 1894), the <a href="United%20States%20Circuit%20Court%20for%20the%20Northern%20District%20of%20Illinois">United States Circuit Court for the Northern District of Illinois</a> (1879 to 1894), and the <a href="United%20States%20Court%20of%20Appeals%20for%20the%20Seventh%20Circuit">United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit</a> from 1891 to 1894.
This federal building was poorly-planned and poorly-built, and by the 1890s was considered dangerous and too small. The building was razed in 1896, and its stone shipped by rail to <a href="Milwaukee">Milwaukee</a>, where it was used to build the <a href="Basilica%20of%20St.%20Josaphat">Basilica of St. Josaphat</a>. The <a href="Chicago%20Federal%20Building">Chicago Federal Building</a> was then built on the same site, and for similar purposes, from 1898 and 1905.
